article.description:
David West scored 26 points, Romain Sato had 25 and Keith Jackson added 21 on Saturday, an inside-outside
balance that helped Xavier (No. 22 ESPN/USA Today, No. 21 AP) pull away to a 99-83 victory over St. Bonaventure.
article.headline: Xavier recovering from injury just fine
article.linkText: Musketeers find punch in beating St. Bonaventure
article.story: CINCINNATI (AP) -- No Lionel Chalmers, no point guard, no depth. With seven minutes left, Xavier (No. 22 ESPN/USA Today, No. 21 AP) was having another of those queasy-stomach moments. This time, the Musketeers pulled together and pulled through. David West scored 26 points, Romain Sato had 25 and Keith Jackson added 21, an inside-outside balance that helped Xavier pull away to a 99-83 victory over St. Bonaventure on Saturday. The Musketeers (10-4, 1-1 Atlantic 10) finally steadied themselves after losing Chalmers, their senior point guard, to a broken foot on Dec. 31. Xavier lost its next two games, its first back-to-back losses in three years. The group effort against St. Bonaventure (6-9, 1-2) restored confidence. ``The chemistry of this team is going to be the key down the stretch,'' West said. ``We just have to make sure everything with this team is positive, and this was a great way to start. Guys did a nice job hanging tough.'' St. Bonaventure used its 10-man rotation and full-court press to wear down the short-handed Musketeers, who were left without a point guard when freshman Dedrick Finn fouled out with 7:12 left. Finn was forced to play 40 minutes in each of the last three games because of Chalmers' injury. The Musketeers led by 19 points when he got his fifth foul, but the Bonnies got no closer than 14 the rest of the way as West and everyone else in the lineup took turns handling the ball. ``They have a very good five or six players, they just don't have more players than that,'' St. Bonaventure coach Jan van Breda Kolff said. ``We thought our pressure would wear them down. They showed a lot of resolve and handled it.'' West was 11-of-16 from the field and had 13 rebounds, bouncing back from his worst game of the season. A worn-out West was 3-of-15 from the field for a season-low 10 points in a home loss to Richmond on Tuesday. ``I don't think they expected us to play as well as we did with the type of up-and-down game and the lack of depth,'' West said. ``We have only one point guard. So this was gratifying.'' Finn guarded Marques Green, the conference's leading scorer at 21.8 points per game. Green had only 11 points on 4-of-16 shooting, while Patricio Prato had 21 for the Bonnies. Xavier came out firing away from the perimeter -- the Bonnies' favorite strategy -- and pulled out to a 36-16 lead midway through the first half. Sato led the way, hitting five of his first six 3-point shots as Xavier went up by 20. Sato, a streaky shooter, was 7-of-10 from the field for 19 points in the half. Sato missed a last-second shot at St. Bonaventure last Feb. 9, allowing the Bonnies to hold on for an 80-79 win. ``Three days ago, Coach (Thad Matta) took me aside for 10 minutes after practice,'' said Sato, who also had 10 rebounds. ``That's when I started feeling good shooting.'' West fouled out of last year's game with Xavier ahead in the closing minutes, opening the way for a decisive 14-3 run by the Bonnies. He got in foul trouble again Saturday, going to the bench with his second foul during a 16-6 run by St. Bonaventure that cut it to 43-34. West walked onto the court after a Xavier turnover, a blue towel draped around his shoulders, encouraging his teammates. Then, he took a seat next to Chalmers, who is expected back at the end of the month. Xavier shot 65.5 percent in the first half, but led only 50-40 as St. Bonaventure -- the nation's top 3-point shooting team last season -- made enough long-range shots to stay close. The Bonnies were 12-of-34 overall on 3s, with nearly half of their shots (34 of 73) coming from behind the arc. When West returned at the start of the second half, the Bonnies' defense again pulled inside, leaving open shots around the arc. Jackson hit two uncontested jumpers and had a three-point play as the Musketeers went ahead 76-51 with 12 minutes left. Green hit three consecutive 3s to get the lead down to 15 again, but West drove the court for a one-handed dunk and had a steal and pass to Jackson for a reverse dunk.
